unnormalised: The Ministry of Textiles has announced a new initiative to standardize units of measurement used in the tailoring industry across India. Currently, measurements are often taken and interpreted differently across various regions and tailoring establishments.
normalised: The Ministry of Textiles has announced a new initiative to standardize units of measurement used in the tailoring industry across India. This comes in response to growing concerns from both consumers and tailors regarding inconsistencies and lack of clarity in sizing conventions. Currently, measurements are often taken and interpreted differently across various regions and tailoring establishments.

unnormalised: The proposed standards will focus on establishing precise definitions for commonly used units like inches ("), centimeters (cm), and meters (m) when measuring fabric, body dimensions, and garment lengths. Furthermore, the initiative aims to promote the use of universally recognized size charts for ready-to-wear clothing. Training programs will be conducted across the country to educate tailors on the new standards, ensuring consistent application of measurements. The project plans to incorporate both traditional units like 'girah' and convert them into metric equivalents for wider adoption.

unnormalised: The first phase of the program will commence in Delhi, Mumbai, and Chennai, with plans for nationwide expansion over the next 18 months. The ministry projects a positive impact on the industry, improving accuracy, reducing alterations, and enhancing customer satisfaction. The project is estimated to cost Rs. 5 crore, with funding allocated for training materials, equipment calibration, and awareness campaigns.
